author: Amber Thomas

intro.value: Over the past 111 days of quarantine, my Netflix account and I have spent a lot of time together. Probably too much time together, honestly. I’ve recently noticed that if I leave the TV app idle, a screensaver cycles through titles on the platform paired with three descriptive words. Things like “charming, witty, funny”.
And over time, I’ve noticed a single, perplexing word used more than the rest...

postTV.value: What started as a joke in the early days of quarantine, eventually became something I couldn’t stop questioning. Why irreverent? Afterall, on my account, it was the most common tag, appearing alongside 26% of advertised titles.

preDef: If, like me, you need a little refresher on the definition of irreverent, don’t feel bad. It’s the only common tag that’s an actual SAT word. Here’s the definition:
def: Irreverent: showing a lack of respect for people or things that are generally taken seriously

postComplaint.value: Interestingly enough, this implies that by definition it shouldn’t be a common descriptor for media. Afterall, if everything is poking fun at things generally taken seriously, is anything taking them seriously? If everything is irreverent, is anything? Either way, I was starting to see the word irreverent in my dreams.

Now, I know what you’re going to say. Netflix’s algorithms are probably surfacing things that it thinks I would like based on my own viewing preferences. It’s certainly possible that I’ve been causing my own irreverent doom.

So, I created a brand new profile with no viewing preferences, which according to Netflix, should display “a diverse and popular set of titles”. Even with this new account, irreverent was the second most common tag.

prePairs.value: That’s so much irreverence. What is going on here? Why is the word irreverent being used so much?

Even though it irks me personally, there may be a reason for using this specific word: it’s what certain viewers want. In a 2012 interview with the Los Angeles Times, the overseer of Netflix’s tagging program, Todd Yellin, described the team’s process of choosing the word cerebral over the more-accessible brainy. He said “...we concluded that if you like cerebral titles, then ‘cerebral’ will be a good word for you”. Since, irreverent is a real genre of comedy, maybe its heavy use throughout Netflix is to specifically target users who know of and enjoy that specific sub-genre.

That may get at why irreverent is used instead of another descriptor (Thesaurus.com suggests the synonyms “cheeky”, “flippant”, or “tongue-in-cheek”), but it doesn’t explain why so many irreverent titles are being surfaced.

For that, we may be able to look to the current state of our world. Sure, when stay-at-home orders first started rippling across the US in March, it seemed like everyone was watching movies about pandemics. But Google searches for “comedy movies” also peaked around that same time. We can’t know for sure if users were looking for irreverent comedies, of course, but if there were ever a time to poke fun at things like our government, wealth, or the way we work… this may be it.

Even researchers agree that watching comedies during times of uncertainty can have a “positive effect”. In an interview with CBC, Dr. Shira Gabriel, an associate professor of psychology at SUNY, University at Buffalo explained that “it can be comforting to make light of the very things that worry us. It can make those things seem less scary and remind us that we are not alone.” Maybe Netflix is doing us a solid by putting these titles front and center, trying to give us a nudge to pick something light during these tough times. Or maybe they’re just letting us know that other users are rewatching The Office or Schitt’s Creek for the umpteenth time and you may want to finally give it a try.
According to a Netflix Spokesperson, irreverent is also a general tag which might be relevant to viewers no matter what they’re in the mood to watch. It caters to everyone.
Either way, if you’re looking for new titles that happen to be irreverent, explore all 141 titles and tags shown to a brand new Netflix profile below.

methods: Methods: All data exhibited in this article were collected from Netflix between April 15 and April 21, 2020. To collect these data, I created a brand new Netflix profile and provided it no viewing preferences. I then visited the main Netflix page for that profile on a computer, where hovering over any title reveals three tags for that title. These were the same tags as those displayed on my TV’s screensaver. I recorded the first 172 unique titles on this main page, then eliminated titles tagged “children & family” or “kids”, leaving me with 141 unique titles. For what it’s worth, “irreverent” was still 3rd most common when kids’ titles were included (following “exciting” and “comedy”). According to a Netflix spokesperson, some titles have several tags and the ones that are shown to users may vary by a users’ viewing preferences, thus, the same title may display different tags to another user than the ones I found.
